legal_basis: Notice is given under section 1 of the Statistics of Trade Act 1947.
title: Quarterly Public Sector Employment Survey

description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: Data should relate to all sites in England, Scotland and Wales unless otherwise stated.
You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.

contents.description: View detailed guidance for completing this survey (this link opens in a new tab)
Explain figures in the comments section to minimise us contacting you and to help us tell an industry story.

contents.description: The survey collects information on the number of employees in the public sector. Information is published in the quarterly Public Sector Employment Statistical Bulletin and is used to understand the performance of the labour market and UK economy, to provide accountability to Parliament and support policy making.

title.text: On {employment_date}, how many male permanent employees did {ru_name} have?

list: agency workers paid directly from any of the organisation's payrolls
those temporarily absent but still on the payrolls, for example on parental leave
agency workers paid directly from the agency payroll
self-employed workers
voluntary workers
former employees only receiving a pension
directors who do not receive a salary

contents.description: This refers to anyone aged 16 years or over that your organisation pays directly from its payroll(s), in return for carrying out a full-time or part-time job or being on a training scheme. Each employee should have a contract of employment.
Permanent employees are those who have a contract with no agreed expiry date or a fixed term contract of more than 12 months. This is regardless of the amount of time remaining on the contract.

answers.label: Number of full-time male permanent employees
Number of part-time male permanent employees
answers.description: Working less than your organisation’s normal weekly hours

title.text: On {employment_date}, how many male permanent full-time equivalent employees did {ru_name} have?

description:
Convert part-time employees hours into those worked by full-time employees. For example, if a part-time employee works 10 hours per week and the full-time working week in your organisation is 37 hours, the part-time employee would equate to 0.27 full-time equivalents (10 divided by 37).

Use weekly contracted hours as the basis to calculate FTE.

question.title: Please comment on any significant changes in the number of employees since the previous quarter

contents.description: Your response will help inform decision-makers how best to support the UK population and economy at this challenging time.
Learn more about how we use this data (this link opens in a new tab)

submission.title: Check your answers and submit
submission.warning: You must submit this survey to complete it
submission.guidance: You will have the opportunity to view, save or print a copy of your answers after submitting this survey.
